title: 108_hr2475
content: The Act titled "Veterans Health Care Full Funding Act" enhances the funding process for veterans' health care programs. The "Veterans Health Care Full Funding Act" amends Chapter 3 of title 38, United States Code by adding a new section for an enhanced funding process for veterans' health care. The Veterans Health Care Funding Review Board determines the funding needed for veterans' health care programs for each fiscal year, with amounts available for obligation for two consecutive fiscal years. The Veterans Health Care Full Funding Act establishes a process for determining funding for veterans' health care programs. The Board considers economic assumptions provided by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. The determined amount for a two-fiscal-year period is included in the budget transmitted to Congress. The Board determines funding needed for veterans' health care programs for a two-fiscal-year period, ensuring it covers the health care needs of enrolled veterans, those with service-connected disabilities, timely access to health care, and maintenance of Department nursing home capacities. The Board determines funding for veterans' health care programs, including maintenance of nursing home capacities, specialized programs, and necessary facility improvements to ensure adequate care for veterans. Unanticipated requirements such as changes in benefits and beneficiaries are also considered. The Board reviews changes in benefits, beneficiaries, economic conditions, and other relevant factors. The review includes demographic information, utilization trends, support for core missions, efficiency of healthcare delivery, and other appropriate factors. The Board submits an annual report to Congress on its determinations and reviews, including amounts determined for fiscal years, economic assumptions, and recommendations for achieving optimal efficiencies. The Board submits an annual report to Congress updating its determinations and recommendations for achieving efficiencies in delivering health care to veterans. The report includes revisions to previous determinations and excludes medical research and grants from veterans health care programs. The Department of Veterans Affairs established a Veterans Health Care Funding Review Board consisting of three members appointed by the Secretary. Members must have backgrounds in health care policy analysis, statistics, insurance, economics, or similar qualifications. Board members serve for 15 years, with exceptions for vacancies. The Veterans Health Care Funding Review Board members serve for 15 years and can only be removed for misconduct or failure to perform duties. Board members who are not federal employees receive pay equivalent to the highest rate of basic pay under the General Schedule for each day of duty and are entitled to travel expenses. The Veterans Health Care Funding Review Board is provided with necessary papers, records, and information to carry out its functions. The Office of Management and Budget must provide economic assumptions to the Board, including those affecting health care costs. Funds for the Board's expenses come from veterans health care programs. The Veterans Health Care Funding Review Board receives necessary information to fulfill its functions, including economic assumptions from the Office of Management and Budget. The Board's expenses are funded by veterans health care programs. The table of sections in the chapter is amended to include budget requirements for determinations under subsection (b). The Veterans Health Care Funding Review Board, established under section 320 of title 38, United States Code, will receive initial funding for operation in fiscal year 2004. The appointment of the Board's initial members must be completed within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. The United States Code, as added by subsection (a), allows for a total amount of $2,000,000 from the Department of Veterans Affairs' Medical Care appropriations for that fiscal year. SEC. 3. ACCESS TO CARE STANDARDS. Access to care standards for veterans seeking primary and specialized care include a 30-day standard for appointment scheduling and completion of visits with providers. The Secretary will establish a waiting time standard for veterans' care appointments and monitor facilities' performance. If the standard is not met, the Secretary can arrange care outside the Department. The amendment will be effective six months after the Act's enactment.
